title: 111_hr2424
content: The Act may be cited as the "Federal Reserve Credit Facility Review Act of 2009". The Congress found that in August 2007, liquidity dried up in credit and securities markets, initially affecting financial firms with interests in mortgage-backed securities. This lack of access to credit spread globally, prompting the Federal Reserve to respond to the financial crisis. The Federal Reserve responded to the financial crisis by establishing a Federal funds rate target range of 0 to 0.25 percent to provide liquidity and stability to the financial markets. The Federal Reserve acknowledged the severity of the crisis by exercising its authority to act in response to unusual circumstances, having done so 11 times since the financial crisis began. This authority had not been exercised since 1934. The Federal Reserve has acted 11 times in response to the financial crisis, exercising its authority to address unusual circumstances. The Board of Governors extended assistance to nonmember institutions for the first time since 1959 and purchased debt obligations to address the crisis. During the financial crisis, the Federal Reserve took unprecedented actions, including purchasing debt obligations from government-sponsored enterprises for the first time since 1981 and establishing joint programs with the Department of the Treasury to aid financial markets. Chairman Ben Bernanke affirmed commitment to transparency in Federal Reserve lending programs during financial crisis. SEC. 3. REVIEWS OF SPECIAL FEDERAL RESERVE CREDIT FACILITIES. Section 714 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to allow the Comptroller General to conduct reviews of credit facilities established by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System or any Federal reserve bank. This includes onsite examinations when deemed necessary. The Comptroller General may review credit facilities established by the Board or any Federal reserve bank, including onsite examinations when necessary, in relation to actions approved by the Board under the Federal Reserve Act or providing temporary assistance to private entities. The Federal Reserve Act allows the Board to act as the lender of last resort and provide temporary assistance to private institutions through credit facilities like the Money Market Investor Funding Facility and Asset-Backed Commercial Paper Money Market Mutual Fund Liquidity Facility. The facilities covered in this subsection include the Money Market Investor Funding Facility, Asset-Backed Commercial Paper Money Market Mutual Fund Liquidity Facility, Term Asset-Backed Securities Loan Facility, Term Auction Facility, Primary Dealer Credit Facility, Commercial Paper Funding Facility, Term Securities Lending Facility, Maiden Lane, LLC. The facilities covered in this subsection include the Commercial Paper Funding Facility, Term Securities Lending Facility, Maiden Lane, LLC, Maiden Lane II, LLC, Maiden Lane III, LLC, Revolving Credit Facility, Reciprocal currency arrangements with foreign central banks, Mortgage Backed Securities Purchase Program. The subsection covers various credit facilities including reciprocal currency arrangements with foreign central banks, Mortgage Backed Securities Purchase Program, and special purpose vehicles conducting lending activities. The authority granted in this subsection will expire after a 5-year period from the enactment date, with a required report on each review conducted. The authority granted in the subsection will expire after a 5-year period from the enactment date, with a required report on each review conducted by the Comptroller General to Congress within 90 days of completion. The report under subparagraph (A) shall include a detailed description of the findings and conclusion of the Comptroller General with respect to the review, along with recommendations for legislative or administrative action. SEC. 4. ACCESS TO RECORDS. Access to Records.--Section 714(d)(1) of title 31, United States Code, is amended to grant the Comptroller General access to officers, employees, contractors, and other agents of any agency or credit facility established by an agency. The Comptroller General may request access at any reasonable time and make copies of records as needed. The Comptroller General may request access to records from any agency or credit facility established by an agency at any reasonable time. The Comptroller General can make and retain copies of the records as deemed appropriate. Amendments allow for access to copies of records and credit facilities established by an agency.
